image.altText: Building erupts into flames in Gaza

items.synopsis: Hamas attacks leave more than 250 Israelis dead and 1,500 injured, with Israeli defence chiefs facing growing scrutiny about intelligence failures. Follow live.

title.children: Israel's security forces face questions over intelligence gaps as Hamas takes dozens hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's public broadcaster KAN News is reporting the Israel Defense Forces have hit the homes of six Hamas leaders inside Gaza. The list includes Yahya Sinwar, who is the leader of Hamas inside Gaza. There is no confirmation the individuals were at home at the time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel strikes homes of Hamas leaders: local media

children.content: Israel's public broadcaster KAN News is reporting the Israel Defense Forces have hit the homes of six Hamas leaders inside Gaza.
The list includes Yahya Sinwar, who is the leader of Hamas inside Gaza.
There is no confirmation the individuals were at home at the time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israelis were woken by a barrage of rockets on their Saturday morning, and while the sirens blared, Hamas militants were breaching the land border. Reuters reported the barrage of rockets served as cover for an unprecedented multi-pronged infiltration of fighters. Most fighters crossed through breaches in land barriers separating Gaza and Israel. They attacked towns near the border, walked onto military bases and reaching into Israel as far as Ofakim, which is 30 kilometres inside the country. Israel has spent hundreds of millions fortifying the border wall between itself and Gaza, announcing in 2021 a smart system, which included sensors, had been completed. It was believed to sit inside the existing steel fence to create a border or buffer zone. Questions are now being asked as to how all these systems failed and communities near the Gaza border were left with very little defences as Hamas invaded.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How far into Israel did Hamas reach?

children.content: (Reuters, AP, Times of Israel)
Israelis were woken by a barrage of rockets on their Saturday morning, and while the sirens blared, Hamas militants were breaching the land border.
Reuters reported the barrage of rockets served as cover for an unprecedented multi-pronged infiltration of fighters.

Most fighters crossed through breaches in land barriers separating Gaza and Israel. They attacked towns near the border, walked onto military bases and reaching into Israel as far as Ofakim, which is 30 kilometres inside the country.

Israel has spent hundreds of millions fortifying the border wall between itself and Gaza, announcing in 2021 a smart system, which included sensors, had been completed. It was believed to sit inside the existing steel fence to create a border or buffer zone.
Questions are now being asked as to how all these systems failed and communities near the Gaza border were left with very little defences as Hamas invaded.
The Israel-Gaza border is broken as part of the attack
(Reuters: Mohammed Fayq Abu Mostafa)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're just joining us, a lot has happened in the past 24 hours. It is believed at least 250 Israelis and 230 Palestinians have been killed. Currently, the Israel military is working to rescue hostages while Gaza prepares for further strikes as retaliation against Hamas. Here is a summary of what's happened so far: Hamas launched an air, sea and land attack on Israel on Saturday morning (local time), where a reported 200 Israelis were initially killed Israel was caught off-guard and Hamas militants reportedly attacked towns and communities near the Gaza border for hours before a defence was mounted Israeli then hit back, trying to regain communities from Hamas and launching airstrikes towards Gaza. These intensified overnight, with several residential buildings hit and destroyed A Hamas rocket barrage into central Israel hit four cities, including Tel Aviv An Israeli army spokesman says fighting is continuing in 22 locations in southern Israel after the initial attack and the situation is not yet under control Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke in a televised address declaring: "We are at war" The Hamas militant group says it is holding “dozens” of Israeli soldiers captive in Gaza There are fears for civilian kidnapping victims too, with Israeli military trying to free hostages that are believed to still be in Israel. Some have been taken across the border into Gaza Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh warned the assault that had begun in Gaza would spread to the West Bank and Jerusalem US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged the Palestinian Authority to restore calm and stability in the West Bank in a call with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas on Saturday, according to the US State Department Prime Minister Anthony Albanese condemned the attack on Israel, saying it had a right to defend itself Israel said it would stop supplying electricity, fuel and goods to Gaza Israeli defence chiefs are facing growing questions over how the disaster could have happened
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How did this all unfold?

children.content: If you're just joining us, a lot has happened in the past 24 hours.
It is believed at least 250 Israelis and 230 Palestinians have been killed.
Currently, the Israel military is working to rescue hostages while Gaza prepares for further strikes as retaliation against Hamas.
Here is a summary of what's happened so far:
Hamas launched an air, sea and land attack on Israel on Saturday morning (local time), where a reported 200 Israelis were initially killed
Israel was caught off-guard and Hamas militants reportedly attacked towns and communities near the Gaza border for hours before a defence was mounted
Israeli then hit back, trying to regain communities from Hamas and launching airstrikes towards Gaza. These intensified overnight, with several residential buildings hit and destroyed
A Hamas rocket barrage into central Israel hit four cities, including Tel Aviv
An Israeli army spokesman says fighting is continuing in 22 locations in southern Israel after the initial attack and the situation is not yet under control
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke in a televised address declaring: "We are at war"
The Hamas militant group says it is holding “dozens” of Israeli soldiers captive in Gaza
There are fears for civilian kidnapping victims too, with Israeli military trying to free hostages that are believed to still be in Israel. Some have been taken across the border into Gaza
Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh warned the assault that had begun in Gaza would spread to the West Bank and Jerusalem

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged the Palestinian Authority to restore calm and stability in the West Bank in a call with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas on Saturday, according to the US State Department
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese condemned the attack on Israel, saying it had a right to defend itself
Israel said it would stop supplying
electricity, fuel and goods to Gaza
Israeli defence chiefs are facing growing questions over how the disaster could have happened

image.altText: Crying child and father walk down road

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others in an unprecedented operation.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: Palestinians wave their national flag and celebrate.

items.synopsis: Gaza is one of the most heavily monitored places on earth, constantly watched by satellites and drones and agents on the ground. And yet, Israeli defence and intelligence had no idea Hamas's carefully coordinated assault was coming, writes Adam Harvey.

title.children: Israeli intelligence failure opens door to surprise Hamas attack

image.altText: A man wearing a broad-brimmed hat stands on a porch with one arm reaching up.

items.synopsis: When Yindjibarndi leader Michael Woodley stood his ground against Andrew Forrest's FMG he had no idea he'd still be fighting for compensation 14 years later. Despite community division and lengthy court battles he's never backed down.

title.children: 'Money, power and influence': One man's fight against Australia's richest man Andrew Forrest

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

image.altText: Burnt debris is scattered on a bare field near a large gum tree.

items.synopsis: In a statement released through NSW Police, the family of Queensland pilot Peter Nally and his three grandchildren ask for privacy as they "grieve and process this tragedy".

title.children: 'No words to describe the grief': Family of pilot, three children killed in plane crash near Gundaroo ask for privacy

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Brodie Kostecki drives his car

items.synopsis: The Bathurst 1000 sees the Gen3 Supercars take to the mountain on the 60th anniversary of the great race. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Shane van Gisbergen pulling away at the front of Bathurst 1000

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Golding has been held up by this! Another car has rally-crossed his way across the grass to get into the pits.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 72: MOFFATT HAS BLOCKED PIT ENTRY!

children.content: James Golding has been held up by this!
Another car has rally-crossed his way across the grass to get into the pits.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Moffatt has slammed into the wall at the dipper! Heavy contact too! He might have hit the inside wall and then slammed into the corner. It came just after the Brad Jones Racing entry of Dale Wood had an engine explode. It's going to bring the third safety car of the day out onto the circuit, but Moffatt is going to bring his car limping into the pits. Moffatt is doing very well to get this car back to the pits - there is a lot of damage. Both Red Bulls have come into the pits, David Russell is going through to reclaim the lead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 71: Safety car!

children.content: James Moffatt has slammed into the wall at the dipper!
Heavy contact too!
He might have hit the inside wall and then slammed into the corner.
It came just after the Brad Jones Racing entry of Dale Wood had an engine explode.
It's going to bring the third safety car of the day out onto the circuit, but Moffatt is going to bring his car limping into the pits.
Moffatt is doing very well to get this car back to the pits - there is a lot of damage.
Both Red Bulls have come into the pits, David Russell is going through to reclaim the lead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Garth Tander has spoken to Fox Sports. He has just watched his teammate David Reynolds drop to 26th after serving a drive through penalty. He believes his team should have been allowed to give the position they illegally took from Broc Feeney back to him. "For as long as I can remember … they've given us the opportunity to redress that under the safety car," he says. "There was absolutely no instruction from race control to do that. "When we actually did it on track, they simply said 'no'. "Frustrating, disappointing, but ultimately there is a long way to go in this race."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 35: Tander bemoans 'frustrating' penalty

children.content: Garth Tander has spoken to Fox Sports.
He has just watched his teammate David Reynolds drop to 26th after serving a drive through penalty.
He believes his team should have been allowed to give the position they illegally took from Broc Feeney back to him.
"For as long as I can remember … they've given us the opportunity to redress that under the safety car," he says.
"There was absolutely no instruction from race control to do that.
"When we actually did it on track, they simply said 'no'.
"Frustrating, disappointing, but ultimately there is a long way to go in this race."

image.altText: Artist's impression of an asteroid collision with Earth.

items.synopsis: In 2020, Oxford philosopher Toby Ord put the chances of "existential catastrophe" for our species during the next century at one in six. But does it really stack up, asks Steven Stern.

title.children: Is there really a 1 in 6 chance of human extinction this century?

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: a group of men stand around on rubble

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

image.altText: A boy next to a burning vehicle.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: A burnt-out shell of a car viewed from the front.

items.synopsis: The gunmen allegedly involved in yesterday's deadly shooting at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north remain on the run, as police reveal the attackers set two getaway cars on fire before fleeing in a third.

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.
